articles.headline: U.S. Fears Iraqis Will Not Keep Up Rebuilt Projects
articles.snippet: After spending $53 billion for relief and reconstruction since 2003, the U.S. is concerned Iraqis won’t be able to maintain the facilities on their own.
articles.abstract: After spending $53 billion for relief and reconstruction since 2003, the U.S. is concerned Iraqis won’t be able to maintain the facilities on their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  In its largest reconstruction effort since the Marshall Plan, the United States government has spent $53 billion for relief and reconstruction in Iraq since the 2003 invasion, building tens of thousands of hospitals, water treatment plants, electricity substations, schools and bridges.

articles.headline: Experienced in Love and Money
articles.snippet: Some advice from those with firsthand experience of divorce may help you avoid the financial pitfalls of a split.
articles.abstract: Some advice from those with firsthand experience of divorce may help you avoid the financial pitfalls of a split.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nobody can relate to the raw, visceral experience of ending a marriage better than someone who has gone through it. So it only seemed right to end my series of columns on money and divorce with a few words of advice from financial experts about what they learned when their own marriages fell apart.

articles.headline: Cadbury Bid Under Study at Hershey
articles.snippet: Any Hershey offer would need to be at least $17 billion and would break from the financial conservatism that has long defined the American chocolate giant.
articles.abstract: Any Hershey offer would need to be at least $17 billion and would break from the financial conservatism that has long defined the American chocolate giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hershey, after months of internal debate, is now considering a bid for the British candy maker Cadbury, a move that would challenge Kraft’s existing $16.7 billion hostile offer for the company, according to people briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: A Hamster Is the Season’s Hottest Toy
articles.snippet: For girls, the season’s hottest toy is a set of fake hamsters; for boys, a series of battle cards and action figures inside small spheres.
articles.abstract: For girls, the season’s hottest toy is a set of fake hamsters; for boys, a series of battle cards and action figures inside small spheres.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who’s laughing now, Elmo?

articles.headline: New Consensus Sees Stimulus Package as Worthy Step
articles.snippet: A variety of economists say that stimulus legislation is helping the economy to grow again.
articles.abstract: A variety of economists say that stimulus legislation is helping the economy to grow again.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Now that unemployment has topped 10 percent, some liberal-leaning economists see confirmation of their warnings that the $787 billion stimulus package President Obama signed into law last February was way too small. The economy needs a second big infusion, they say.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: An Unsteady Future for Broadcast
articles.snippet: Analysts and executives are wondering if the economic model of broadcast television, which is more heavily reliant on advertising than cable, is irreparably broken.
articles.abstract: Analysts and executives are wondering if the economic model of broadcast television, which is more heavily reliant on advertising than cable, is irreparably broken.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oprah Winfrey is fleeing broadcast television for cable. NBC, once arguably the biggest cultural tastemaker in the United States, is being shopped to Comcast, the country’s largest cable company.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Bill Carter

articles.headline: Afghan Militias Battle Taliban With Aid of U.S.
articles.snippet: The Americans hope militias will encourage a demoralized Afghan population to take a stake in the war against the Taliban.
articles.abstract: The Americans hope militias will encourage a demoralized Afghan population to take a stake in the war against the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: ACHIN, Afghanistan  American and Afghan officials have begun helping a number of anti-Taliban militias that have independently taken up arms against insurgents in several parts of Afghanistan, prompting hopes of a large-scale tribal rebellion against the Taliban.

articles.headline: High-Tech Devices Help Drivers Put Down Phone
articles.snippet: Which is safer: technology that disables a cellphone in a moving car, or that makes the conversation completely hands-free?
articles.abstract: Which is safer: technology that disables a cellphone in a moving car, or that makes the conversation completely hands-free?
articles.lead_paragraph: Dede Haskins’s cellphone has been her constant companion for more than a decade. And she has always considered herself a careful driver  even using a hands-free set so she could keep both hands on the wheel.

articles.headline: A Terror Suspect With Feet in East and West
articles.snippet: The profile that has emerged of David Headley, a U.S. citizen accused of plotting revenge against a Danish newspaper, suggests a man pulled between two cultures.
articles.abstract: The profile that has emerged of David Headley, a U.S. citizen accused of plotting revenge against a Danish newspaper, suggests a man pulled between two cultures.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA  The trip from a strict Pakistani boarding school to a bohemian bar in Philadelphia has defined David Headley’s life, according to those who know the middle-age man at the center of a global terrorism investigation.

articles.headline: Best Soup Ever? Suits Over Ads Demand Proof
articles.snippet: Companies that were once content to fight in store aisles and on commercials are choosing a different route — formal grievances challenging their competitors’ claims.
articles.abstract: Companies that were once content to fight in store aisles and on commercials are choosing a different route — formal grievances challenging their competitors’ claims.
articles.lead_paragraph: A diamond is forever? Prove it.

articles.headline: Go Ahead and Yell. He’s Everyone’s Punching Bag.
articles.snippet: Day in, day out, Norman Radow deals with the unpleasantries of the real estate mess. He works for lenders to revive developments gone awry.
articles.abstract: Day in, day out, Norman Radow deals with the unpleasantries of the real estate mess. He works for lenders to revive developments gone awry.
articles.lead_paragraph: ESTERO, Fla.

articles.headline: At a Software Powerhouse, the Good Life Is Under Siege
articles.snippet: SAS, the giant private company that specializes in business intelligence software, is facing new rivals, as well as free alternatives to some of its products.
articles.abstract: SAS, the giant private company that specializes in business intelligence software, is facing new rivals, as well as free alternatives to some of its products.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARY, N.C.

articles.headline: Revisiting a Fed Waltz With A.I.G.
articles.snippet: A government report on the bailout of A.I.G. is must reading for taxpayers looking to know why the $182 billion “rescue” is the most troubling episode of the financial disaster.
articles.abstract: A government report on the bailout of A.I.G. is must reading for taxpayers looking to know why the $182 billion “rescue” is the most troubling episode of the financial disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: A RAY of sunlight broke through the Washington fog last week when Neil M. Barofsky, special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program, published his office’s report on the government bailout last year of the American International Group.

articles.headline: Wall St. Finds Profits by Reducing Mortgages
articles.snippet: Investment funds are buying mortgages, trimming some of them to the benefit of homeowners, and shifting any risk to the federal government.
articles.abstract: Investment funds are buying mortgages, trimming some of them to the benefit of homeowners, and shifting any risk to the federal government.
articles.lead_paragraph: As millions of Americans struggle to hold on to their homes, Wall Street has found a way to make money from the mortgage mess.

articles.headline: Supercomputing for the Masses
articles.snippet: A drop in the price of supercomputers and other advances are pulling down the high walls around computing-intensive research, possibly democratizing the field.
articles.abstract: A drop in the price of supercomputers and other advances are pulling down the high walls around computing-intensive research, possibly democratizing the field.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore.  For decades, the world’s supercomputers have been the tightly guarded property of universities and governments. But what would happen if regular folks could get their hands on one?

articles.headline: Looking for a Leader in the Post-Oprah Landscape
articles.snippet: A wide range of contenders, some of them linked to Oprah Winfrey herself, will vie for the dominant role in daytime.
articles.abstract: A wide range of contenders, some of them linked to Oprah Winfrey herself, will vie for the dominant role in daytime.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is no single replacement for Oprah Winfrey.

articles.headline: Some Rivals Weigh Bids for Cadbury
articles.snippet: Cadbury has spent months stonewalling Kraft Foods’ hostile offer. But the entrance of another bidder could help its negotiating position against Kraft.
articles.abstract: Cadbury has spent months stonewalling Kraft Foods’ hostile offer. But the entrance of another bidder could help its negotiating position against Kraft.
articles.lead_paragraph: The contest for Cadbury could become a little more crowded.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Wave of Debt Payments Facing U.S. Government
articles.snippet: The ultralow interest rates the U.S. has been paying on its colossal debt may not last much longer, and the White House estimates that the tab will exceed $700 billion a year in 2019.
articles.abstract: The ultralow interest rates the U.S. has been paying on its colossal debt may not last much longer, and the White House estimates that the tab will exceed $700 billion a year in 2019.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States government is financing its more than trillion-dollar-a-year borrowing with i.o.u.’s on terms that seem too good to be true.

articles.headline: As Sewers Fill, Waste Poisons Waterways
articles.snippet: Many sewer systems are overwhelmed, spilling excrement, medical waste and chemicals into waterways.
articles.abstract: Many sewer systems are overwhelmed, spilling excrement, medical waste and chemicals into waterways.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was drizzling lightly in late October when the midnight shift started at the Owls Head Water Pollution Control Plant, where much of Brooklyn’s sewage is treated.

articles.headline: In Chicago, Ex-Editor Fights Back
articles.snippet: Internet-based local news organizations are drawing big-name journalists, including veterans of the established news outlets they are competing with.
articles.abstract: Internet-based local news organizations are drawing big-name journalists, including veterans of the established news outlets they are competing with.
articles.lead_paragraph: James E. O’Shea spent most of his career at The Chicago Tribune, but he was ousted from the Tribune Company in a highly publicized clash over staff cuts, and these days he’s finding plenty of fault with his old paper.

articles.headline: A Triumph of Avoiding the Traps
articles.snippet: Oprah Winfrey’s gut intuition, about knowing when to say no and when it is time to go, is worth studying at every business school in the country.
articles.abstract: Oprah Winfrey’s gut intuition, about knowing when to say no and when it is time to go, is worth studying at every business school in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you look at Oprah Winfrey’s multidecade run through daytime talk  most of it at No. 1  it’s easy to be impressed by what she did to make it happen. But her longevity and success (Forbes estimated her net worth at over $2.3 billion) probably has more to do with what she did not do.

articles.headline: Prisoner Swap Appears Near in the Mideast
articles.snippet: Hundreds of prisoners could be exchanged for the Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit, and officials said the deal would likely include Marwan Barghouti, a popular West Bank leader.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of prisoners could be exchanged for the Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit, and officials said the deal would likely include Marwan Barghouti, a popular West Bank leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Israel and the Islamist group Hamas appeared Monday to be nearing a deal to exchange a captured Israeli soldier for hundreds of Palestinian prisoners, possibly including a popular leader, a move with far-reaching implications not only for stalled Middle East peace talks but for a range of regional relations.
